title-group.article-title: Reinforcement of starch/polyvinyl alcohol blend using nano‐titanium dioxide

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Chemical Engineering, King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
2Center of Excellence in Nanotechnology (CENT), King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia

author-notes.corresp: PA Sreekumar, Department of Chemical Engineering, King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia Email: sreekumarpa2008@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The article reports the results of the studies on the effect of nano‐titanium dioxide (TiO2) on the morphology, thermal, and mechanical properties of 1:1 starch/polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) composites. Degree of crystallinity of the starch/PVA blends increases with increase in the amount of nano‐TiO2 as determined by differential scanning calorimeter and X‐ray diffraction studies. Results of stress–strain studies indicate an increase in the tensile properties and a decrease in the percentage of elongation and energy at break particularly at higher amount of nano‐TiO2. Increase in peak width in the differential thermogram plot for the maximum decomposition temperature is indicative of increased blend heterogeneity in the presence of nanofillers. The degree of swelling in water decreases with increase in filler loading due to filler–matrix bonding.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: For the last several decades, concern regarding the long‐term adverse effects of large‐scale random usage of plastics on the environment has triggered the interest in the development of biodegradable plastic materials. Among various natural polymers, starch can be used for the preparation of thermoplastic materials.1–3 They are biodegradable, renewable, and of low cost. Starch is a mixture of linear amylose and branched amylopectin. The major disadvantages of these materials are low impact resistance, strong water absorption, and poor mechanical properties. Several studies have been conducted to improve the properties of thermoplastic starch by blending with other thermoplastic polymers as well as by incorporating the fillers.4–9 However, the hydrophilicity of starch results in incompatibility with synthetic polymers.

Starch can be blended with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) using extrusion or solvent cast method in order to improve its elongation and processability,10–12 even though the prolonged contact of these blends with atmosphere results in high moisture absorption and fall in mechanical properties. Sreekumar et al.13 recently reported use of optimal amount of glycerol as a plasticizer in starch/PVA blends. Earlier studies indicated that incorporation of nanofillers such as nanoclay, nano‐SiO2 into polymer matrices increase the mechanical properties with consequent decrease in its moisture absorption.14–17 Tang et al.18,19 prepared nano‐SiO2 reinforced starch/PVA composites by using solution casting method and found that increase in the amount of nano‐SiO2 can improve the tensile strength and water resistance of the composites. This has been attributed to the strong chemical bond formation between nano‐SiO2 and starch/PVA blend. Ardakani et al.20 reported that the relative proportion of water, PVA, and nanoclay can affect the properties of the thermoplastic starch/PVA composites, and that the interaction between citric acid and starch/PVA matrix, as well as the d‐spacing of nanoclay as responsible for the improvement in the tensile strength and modulus of the composites.

Nano‐TiO2 has received special interest as filler in the polymer matrices because of their specific properties such as hydrophilic nature and photo catalytic activity.21–26 Lou et al.21 studied the dispersity and the effect of surface‐carboxylated nano‐TiO2 on the mechanical properties of the PVA. The results show that high dispersion of the modified nano‐TiO2 causes an increase in the tensile strength of the nanocomposites compared with the unmodified nano‐TiO2. The effect of surface modified nano‐TiO2 on the mechanical and morphological properties of polypropylene and high density polyethylene matrix composite was studied by Altan et al.22 Zhang and co‐workers23 analyzed the performance of nano‐TiO2 in high impact polystyrene matrix and reported that the maximum improvement in the tensile properties was obtained for the composites having 2 wt% nano‐TiO2. The addition of nano‐TiO2 also increased the thermo‐resistance and mechanical properties of epoxy resin.24 Panaitescu et al.25 studied the mechanical properties of rutile and anatase nano‐TiO2 reinforced polyethylene composites. No significant differences were observed in the mechanical and morphological characteristics of both composites, except for a higher increase of the elastic modulus in the case of anatase‐containing composites.

The present study was undertaken to study the overall performance of these composites. This article also reports the results of studies on the effect of nano‐TiO2 on the structure, mechanical, thermal, and water absorption properties of starch/PVA composites at 1:1 starch/PVA composition.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Corn starch was provided by ARASCO Corn products, Dammam, Saudi Arabia. Glycerol and PVA (Mw, 27,000; degree of hydrolysis, 98–98.8 mol%), nano‐TiO2 (rutile) of particle size (<100 nm) and Sorbitan monooctadecanoate (Span 60, dispersing agent, molecular weight: 430.62) were procured from Sigma Aldrich.

sec.title: Preparation of composites
sec.p:
Nano‐TiO2 filled starch/PVA composites, with formulations as given in Table 1, were prepared using solution cast method. Initially the suspension of nano‐TiO2 in distilled water at various concentrations of nano‐TiO2 (i.e. 0.5, 1, and 2 wt% with respect to the total polymer content (10 g starch and 10 g PVA)) were prepared using Ultrasonicator. Span 60 (0.01 wt%) was used as the dispersing agent during the ultrasonication. The suspension was ultrasonicated for 1 h and then added slowly to starch/PVA solution (1:1) containing 3.5 g of glycerol while stirring continuously. The loading of glycerol was chosen on the basis of results from a previous study.13 The mixture was stirred for 1 h more at 80°C and casted into a glass plate placed on a leveled flat surface. The composites were allowed to dry at 40°C in an air oven for 16 h. The dried membranes were peeled away from the plate, and then compressed in a Carver press at 120°C for 10 min. Table 1.
Tcry, Tm, ΔHcry, ΔHm and degree of crystallinity of starch/PVA composites containing different amounts of nano‐TiO2.a
Nano‐TiO2 loading (wt%) Tcry (°C) ΔHcry (J/g) Tm (°C) ΔHfus (J/g) Crystallinity (%)
0 179 21.79 206 15.75 22
0.5 196 26.03 215 18.33 26
1 197 28.68 216 19.76 28
2 196 27.29 218 17.27 24
a
Formulations consist of 10 g of corn starch, 10 g of PVA and 3.5 g of glycerol in 200 mL water.

sec.title: DSC analysis
sec.p: The melting and crystallization behavior of the blends were determined by using DSC‐Q1000, Universal V4.2E TA Instruments. Heating and cooling for both first and second cycles were done in nitrogen atmosphere at the rate of 10°C/min from a temperature of − 50°C to 240°C. Calibrations in DSC were done by measuring the temperature and the enthalpy of melting of indium.

sec.title: XRD analysis
sec.p: X‐ray diffractometer used was LABX XRD‐6000, Shimadzu. X‐rays of 1.5410 Å wavelength was generated by Cu Kα source. The angle of diffraction (2θ) was varied from 10° to 60°. The degree of crystallinity of the samples was measured using the curve fitting method. A smooth curve that connected peak baselines was computer‐plotted on the diffractograms. The area above the smooth curve was taken as the crystalline portion, and the lower area between the smooth curve and the linear baseline which connected the two points of the intensity 2θ of 60° and 10° in the samples was taken as the amorphous section. The ratio of upper area to total diffraction was taken as the degree of crystallinity. The degree of crystallinity was calculated as follows (1)Xc=Ac(Ac+Aa) where Xc refers to the degree of crystallinity; Ac refers to the crystallized area on the X‐ray diffractogram, and Aa refers to the amorphous area on the X‐ray diffractogram.

sec.title: Thermogravimetric analysis
sec.p: Thermal degradation studies were performed by thermogravimetric measurements using TGA‐Q500 (TA instruments). Samples weighing approximately 10 mg were heated in nitrogen atmosphere (purge gas flow: 50 mL/min) from 25° to 800°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min.

sec.title: Tensile properties
sec.p: Tensile tests were carried out by using a universal testing machine (Instron model 5560). The tests were performed according to ASTM D 638–03 standard. Tensile samples were prepared by cutting dumbbell samples from the films by using ASTM Die C. The data presented correspond to the average value of five measurements.

sec.title: Degree of swelling in water
sec.p: The degree of swelling test was conducted using 20 mm × 20 mm × 1 mm films. The specimens were dried at 40°C, then cooled in a desiccator and immediately weighed. The conditioned specimens were fully immersed in a container filled with distilled water at room temperature for 24 h, by which time equilibrium swelling is believed to occur.27 Then each specimen was taken out of the container, the surface water being removed by adsorbing with filter paper, and then weighed. The samples were then kept in the oven for drying and weighed again. The result of each sample represents the average of five tests. The degree of swelling in water was calculated using the equation (2)Degree of swelling(%)=(Wa-W0/W0)×100 where Wa is the weight of the sample after 24 h; W0 is the initial weight of the sample.

sec.title: Results and discussions
sec.p:
The DSC thermograms of starch/PVA composites as a function of amount of nano‐TiO2 are given in Figure 1. It can be seen that all the composites show an endothermic peak at its melting stage and ΔHfus, ΔHcry, Tcry, and Tm along with the percentage of crystallinity as a function of amount of nano‐TiO2 are summarized in Table 1. The nucleating effect of nano‐TiO2 on the crystallization of PVA component in the blend causes an increase in the Tm, ΔHfus, ΔHcry, and Tcry values. It has been shown earlier that the crystallization of the PVA component is adversely affected by the starch in the starch/PVA blend.28 Incorporation nano‐TiO2 tends to oppose this process. The percentage of crystallinity (normalized with respect to the amount of polyvinyl alcohol) was calculated using the following expression and is given in Table 1. (3)% of crystallinity=(ΔHfus/ΔHfus0)×100 where ΔHfus is the enthalpy of fusion of the starch/PVA composite based on second heating scan and ΔH0fus is the enthalpy of fusion of the 100% crystalline PVA. ΔH0fus of PVA was taken as 142 J/g.29 Incorporation of 1 wt% of nano‐TiO2 increases the percentage of crystallinity of the starch/PVA, while further increase in the concentration of the nanofiller does not cause significant variation in the crystallinity. Results of XRD studies, as discussed below, are in agreement with the results of DSC studies. Figure 1.
DSC heating and cooling curves for the nano‐TiO2 filled starch/PVA composites. Figures on the plots refer to the wt% of nano‐TiO2.

X‐ray diffraction plots for the nano‐TiO2 reinforced starch/PVA composites are shown in Figure 2. For the starch/PVA blend designated as (0) the prominent peak appears at 19.6°, 22.2°, and 40.8°. The peak at 19.6° and 40.8° are the characteristic peaks of PVA30 while the peak at 22.2° represents the V‐hydrate (Vh) crystalline type structure of starch.31 In the case of composites, additional peaks appear at 27°, 36°, 37°, 43°, and 54°, which correspond to the characteristic peaks of nano‐TiO2.32 Variation in the d‐spacing, peak width (FWHM) values, and the intensity of the peaks are summarized in Table 2. It's interesting to note that the incorporation of nano‐TiO2 to starch/PVA matrix causes a decrease in the peak height and width of 19.6° and 40.8°, which are characteristic peaks of PVA. This is believed to be due to the intermolecular hydrogen bonding between the OH groups present on nano‐TiO221 and PVA. It is evident from Table 2 that the percentage of crystallinity for the blends increases on addition of 1 wt% of nano‐TiO2, but crystallinity does not show any further change with increase in nanofiller loading. This is corroborated by the results of DSC analysis, as discussed previously. The differences in the crystallinity obtained by using XRD and DSC are due to the difference in the measuring methods.22 Figure 2.
XRD plots for the nano‐TiO2 filled starch/PVA composites. Table 2.
X‐ray diffraction parameters and degree of crystallinity of starch/PVA composites containing different amounts of nano‐TiO2
Nano‐TiO2 loading (wt%) Angle d‐ value FWHM I Crystallinity (%)
0 19.66 4.51 1.83 13,119 10
22.24 3.99 1.92 3235
40.82 2.26 7.30 3149
0.5 19.89 4.46 1.46 10,114 12
22.25 3.82 0.81 640
27.85 3.20 0.40 565
36.47 2.46 0.12 63
37.52 2.39 0.08 139
40.98 2.20 1.55 836
43.72 2.06 0.13 126
54.68 1.67 0.20 107
1 19.92 4.45 1.86 9485 13
22.99 3.86 2.65 5437
27.96 3.18 0.16 39
36.60 2.45 0.24 111
37.51 2.39 0.06 191
40.15 2.19 1.57 1361
43.74 2.06 0.11 241
54.79 1.67 0.20 159
2 20.15 4.40 1.30 4299 12
27.77 3.20 0.13 1180
36.40 2.46 0.13 493
37.49 2.39 0.11 116
41.62 2.16 0.35 477
54.63 1.67 0.15 530
56.94 1.61 0.14 134

The thermogravimetric (TG) and differential thermogram (DTG) plots for the starch, PVA and starch/PVA composites are given in Figures 3 and 4. For the composites the mass loss occurs in four stages in the temperature of 50–200°C; 200–275°C; 275–400°C, and 450–500°C. The initial mass loss (T1) below 200°C is due to the evaporation of water and glycerol used during the preparation of the composites.33 The results of the thermogravimetric analysis are summarized in Table 3. It had been reported earlier that neat PVA shows three peaks at 187°C, 285°C, and 436°C, the maximum degradation occurring at 285°C, while the neat starch shows three peaks at 100°C, 326°C, and 432°C, the maximum degradation occurring at 326°C.28 In the present case of 1:1 starch/PVA blend the maximum degradation (designated as Tmax) occurs around 320°C. However, the peaks due to PVA (T2) as well as polyene residue in both starch and PVA (T3) are also present in the blend.34 The T2 value in the case of blend is believed to be due to the shifting of the PVA degradation peak from 285°C to 221°C, presumably arising out of the increased blend heterogeneity.13 The T2, Tmax, and T3 values are not affected by the incorporation of nano‐TiO2. But it is observed that the DTG peaks of the maximum degradation temperature for the unfilled starch/PVA blend are sharp and the peak width is narrow, while addition of nano‐TiO2 into the starch/PVA matrix results in an increase in the degradation peak width, which is attributed to the increase in the blend heterogeneity.13 In order to make a comparison, the calculated peak widths at all compositions (i.e. ΔT, the difference in temperature at the start of degradation and at the end of the degradation) at the DTG point of 0.40%/min are 55°C, 75°C, 75°C, 77°C for 0, 0.5, 1, and 2 wt% nano‐TiO2 loading, respectively. This increase in the ΔT is indicative of increase in degree of heterogeneity beyond 1 wt% nanofiller loading.28 The extent of interaction between nano‐TiO2 and PVA, and between nano‐TiO2 and starch may cause decrease in the partial miscibility of the PVA/starch blend system causing an increase in the blend heterogeneity. This is corroborated by the tensile properties as discussed below. Figure 3.
TG plots for the nano‐TiO2 filled starch/PVA composites. Figure 4.
DTG plots for the PVA and nano‐TiO2 filled starch/PVA composites. Table 3.
Results of thermogravimetric studies of the starch/PVA composites containing different amounts of nano‐TiO2
Nano‐TiO2 loading (wt%) Mass loss at 200°C (%) T2 Tmax (°C) T3 (°C) Residue (%)
0 9 221 320 428 5
0.5 9 227 321 430 8
1 12 227 321 427 7
2 10 228 322 429 8

Figure 5 represents the stress‐strain behavior of nano‐TiO2 filled starch/PVA composites and the results are summarized in Table 4. Incorporation of nano‐TiO2 causes an increase in the Young's modulus and tensile strength of starch/PVA blend. The effect is apparent at the nanofiller loading of 0.5 and 1 wt%. This increment is due to the intermolecular hydrogen bonding between the adsorbed water molecules on the nano‐TiO2 surface with that of starch and PVA.35 As the filler loading increases further, both modulus and tensile strength decrease. It is believed that the interfacial adhesion between nano‐TiO2 and starch/PVA matrix becomes less effective at higher filler loading due to agglomeration of the nanofiller particles in the polymer matrix. This ultimately causes a poor dispersion of the nano‐filler in the matrix. Table 4 also shows a drop in elongation and energy at break in the presence of nano‐TiO2. Figure 5.
Stress‐strain plots for the nano‐TiO2 filled starch/PVA composites. Nano‐TiO2 loading in wt% is shown on the curves. Table 4.
Stress‐strain properties of the starch/PVA composites containing different amounts of nano‐TiO2
Nano‐TiO2 loading (wt%) Tensile strength (MPa) Young's modulus (MPa) Elongation (%) Energy at break (J/m2)
0 10.4 ± 0.5 365 ± 5 10.6 ± 0.6 95.3 ± 9
0.5 14.7 ± 0.3 464 ± 9 6.6 ± 0.4 73.0 ± 6
1 15.3 ± 0.4 491 ± 6 5.9 ± 0.2 65.2 ± 3
2 13.9 ± 0.6 451 ± 10 5.7 ± 0.3 61.5 ± 4

The degree of swelling of starch/PVA nanocomposites is displayed in Figure 6. It can be seen that the degree of swelling of the composites decrease with increase in the amount of nano‐TiO2. This is attributed to the network structure formed between the nano‐TiO2 and starch/PVA, which ultimately prevents the absorption of water molecules thereby improving the water resistance. Similar trend has been observed by Tang et al.18 in the case of nano‐SiO2 reinforced starch/PVA composites. Figure 6.
Plots of degree of swelling in water for the nano‐TiO2 filled starch/PVA composites.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The crystallinity of the starch/PVA blend increases on incorporation of nano‐TiO2 and attains a maximum for the composites having 1 wt% of nano‐TiO2. Tensile strength and Young's modulus increase with increase in filler loading till 1 wt% of nanofiller beyond which the strength decreases. However, the energy at break and percentage elongation decreases at all loadings. Increase in peak width at the maximum decomposition temperature in the DTG plots reveal an increase in the blend heterogeneity and a fall in ductility of the composites particularly at higher loading of nano‐TiO2. The degree of swelling in water decreases at all filler loadings due to the filler‐matrix bonding.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not‐for‐profit sectors.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they do not have any conflict of interest.
